author: XerxesDGreat
title: Feels Overpriced, But A Great Set
review:
While I think this set is great, I purchased it at the same time as 75099 (Rey's Speeder) which had more pieces and was 33% cheaper. I know that the pieces in this set are much more specialized and fancy than the parts for the speeder, but I can't help feeling a little ripped off for spending $10 more for fewer pieces.

Box/Instructions

Instructions were mostly clear; box was properly sized. Only issue I had was the typical one I have with dark sets: figuring out exactly which grey was which.

Parts

Not many generally reusable parts, but the ones there work excellently for the CCBS system

Minifigures

n/a

The build

Fairly simple; took me about an hour. Nothing fancy, just making sure that the pieces are aligned correctly.

 

The completed model

LOVE this model! Totally poseable, very easy to play with; my four-year-old can play endlessly with it!

 

Overall opinion

Not disappointed with the model, even though it was more expensive than I felt it should be. Still glad that I bought it though!

author: david001
title: "More machine now than man ..."
review:
As part of the brand-new LEGO Battle Figures sets, I must admit to initially being a bit unsure about how these would look.

However, I decided to take the plunge on Darth Vader as I do feel that the figures 'look' better when representing those who are largely machines ,or wearing armour.

Upon starting to build the model, it's immediately obvious that it comes more from a Technic background than from a 'standard' Lego background, making use of multiple ball-joints and Technic pins, for example.

Thankfully, it also uses printed pieces (rather than stickers) for Vader's chest-piece and lights - a big plus in my book :)

The final model is impressive, standing roughly 30cm tall, and fully poseable.  However, it can be hard to balance.

author: Parkerlegomaster
title: luke... I am your father
review:
Box/Instructions

Instructions are easy to read. Comes in a standard Lego box.

Parts

Com s with a lot of ultra build parts and some exclusive pieces suc as darth vader's helmet.

Mini-figures

No minifigures are included in this set

The build

Took a little longer to build than e average Lego set because I am not the biggest ultrabuild builder.

The completed model

The completed model is ok because it is hard to make it stand up and I am not the biggest fan of the way they put the cape on.

Overall opinion

I think the overall rating is "fine" lol

author: legochuck
title: Great for your Father, not as much for your Luke.
review:
As the second Lego Darth Vader buildable figure, I feel this incarnation of our favorite Sith Lord lives up to its predecessor, although it lacks in some areas.

Parts

There is a great parts selection in this set, especially if you enjoy building with the CCBS system.  Most notable is the helmet piece, which is printed on the front, and offers an excellent level of detail.  The cape really makes the model, and the printed breast plates definitely add to the overall look of the set. 

The Build

The build is surprisingly complex for this model, offering up a lot of technic building in the torso section.  Even with the robust technic build, the shape of the body is very well done and smooth.  The arms and legs are pretty much standard to the CCBS system, with the exception of the rear calf, which is made up of some technic parts and black teeth.  The only complaint about the build is the slightly bulky shoulders, which cause the build to look more muscular than robotic. 

The Completed model

The completed model stands almost eleven inches tall and is great for display on a shelf or desk.  Although you can play with the model, there are no action features in his saber wielding hand, which would have been nice for playability.  Joint articulation is good but not great, as the elbows do not bend as well as they could without twisting the fore-arms to the side.  It is also rather easy to disconnect the legs or feet joints, as they are only connected by rigid ball and socket lengtheners.  It works well for pose-ability, but not as well for play.  Overall however, the armor looks great and gives a nice sense of realism to the entire model.

Overall opinion

I would definitely recommend this set to anyone interested in Star Wars and Lego.  Its a great piece to pose on a desk and it looks good for multiple angles.  For play, it does lack some features that could really make it stellar, but I think kids would still enjoy having the classic villain in their collection.

author: Minifig290
title: One Of The Best Build-able Figures EVER
review:
When LEGO started selling the Star Wars Buildable Figure line in late 2015 people were excited for the Darth Vader figure which was the second most pricey of the 6 released. But as the Sub-theme continued the sets got worse and pricing also got worse but Darth Vader was always a strong seller that is probably why they redid it in 2018.

This set sells for £25 and has 160 parts with a 15.6p price per part.

Build

Darth Vader is the only build in this set and he is marvelous. His head piece is very detailed with small bits of silver printing on. His torso consist of a printed chest piece that is has great printing on it with a sign that has printing for some buttons etc.

Both of his arms are identical that have a printed arm plate for some detail. Same with his legs but they have some more parts to them. Vader is holding a light saber in his left arm that uses a new (at the time) trans red part that is a rubbery plastic material. His cape is of the newer and softer cloth and attaches from the neck and chest.

Parts

There are 6 exclusive parts in the set, his torso has three exclusive parts one of which is a road sign that has some technical print on it. Also his head is also only i this set, while his cape is only in this set and the newer 2018 Darth Vader (as im aware of). Also there are 6 printed panels that only come in this set.

__________________________________________________________________________

Overall

For a set that was to introduce a new Sub theme for star wars it is brilliant. There are a lot of great parts and detail. This set is full of play features so you can move his arms and legs and head and lightsaber.

Definitely worth buying and is better than the 2018 version by miles as he is perfectly sized, priced and full of great features.

Pros- Great play features, It is priced well enough and perfectly sized

Cons- None To Mention

author: alfred_the_buttler
title: Best of the buildable figure sets
review:
So I really had no interest in these buildable figure sets as I didn’t really think they were truly Lego sets, but then I found 7 sets for $30 at a garage sale so figured why not. I got Darth Vader, Luke, Obiwan, a Clone Trooper, Finn, Captain Phasma, and a Storm Trooper. This Darth Vader set is easily the biggest, most detailed, and the best. 

The piece count is of course the highest and that is due primarily to his elaborate torso which is mostly built. Other buildable figures only have a plate that snaps on in front. So If you enjoy building, Darth Vader is the only set that really allows you to build. Are they Legos? Well that’s debatable, some parts are but many are unique to this building system which is very un-Lego-like but does incorporate a little bit of technic parts. For the most part this system is simple to build so the complex torso makes this fun. 

In the end you wind up with a buildable action figure that has some pretty amazing details given it is built almost entirely of modular parts. While it is fairly durable, I don’t think it would hold up well with my 4 year old playing with it, and my 2 year old definitely would destroy it. From a playability point of view I’d say all sets are equal with an exception for Finn who has a mechanical component to his arm, although I’m not sure a young child would appreciate that as much since you could always just move his arm  

At the end of the day, these sets were worth the price I paid, and definitely make more sense when you have many so that you can play with them together. But I would never pay the retail price for these sets. For that same price I’d rather buy a regular action figure and a regular Lego set which would offer a lot more to play with, especially since my kids are too young even to play with an already built figure.
